reviewText:
For me, finding this game was a bit like finding a coin lying in the street.  For a freebie, its surprisingly fun.  Though very simple in its presentation, it is still a lot of fun to play.

The game has no story to it.  The player is given a small spaceship, some basic equipment, and a little money, then set loose in a random star system to roam the galaxy as they please.  Money can be found by breaking open asteroids or blowing up other ships, most of which are hostile.

The controls are very simple and appear to be based on the classic Asteroids game.  The player can rotate their ship, thrust forward, and shoot, although some ships can equip secondary weapons.  Each of the many playable ships also has a special ability, such as the ability to slow time for a few seconds, or knock down the shields of all nearby enemies, although these abilities use charges, which can be purchased at shops or recovered from destroyed enemies.  Most weapons, not including the basic blaster, require ammunition as well.  Blowing up enemies is a bit like smashing a pinata, as the loot scatters from the wreckage in the form of multi-coloured icons.

A small on-screen menu allows the player to open their inventory to change equipment, and interact with certain friendly ships and stations, as well as access a system map or adjust the options ingame.  You can dock with friendly stations and trader ships to buy and sell equipment, change your ship, or even hire mercenaries to fight alongside you.

The RPG elements in the game are very basic.  The player becomes more powerful by buying or salvaging new equipment, or buying new ships (all equipment in the player's inventory is transferred).  The map is very simple and requires little explanation.  A skull-and-crossbones symbol marks areas with enemies that are significantly more powerful than your current ship.  As you get better ships and equipment, these symbols disappear, showing that you can safely progress to more dangerous areas.

Among the locations the player can visit are asteroid fields, where the drifting rocks are particularly dense, planets, where the player must contend with gravity and bombard surface structures to survive, and floating labyrinths, where the player must carefully navigate the interior of complex structures and battle their internal defences.

It's not perfect.  The game is quite small and only features a couple of systems so far, although it is apparently still being worked on.  The game automatically saves your ship and its inventory, but not its location, so each time you return to the game, you arrive back in a random system.  There is no background music and the gameplay is mostly limited to flying around in search of things to shoot, but for a free game it's not bad at all.

Destination Sol is 2D Space Arcade Shooter. Explore a hostile corner of the galaxy, fighting off pirates and enemy crafts, mining asteroids and upgrading your ship and equipment.

Pros: You get to explore asteroid fields, giant space mazes and caves, you can land on planets in orbit, whose gravity effect is neatly realized: as you approach, the screen rotates to the incoming gravity force, pulling you in as you bomb enemy towers or land of ports. Such ports, as well as port-ships flying about, allow you to land to sell off salvage and buy better ships and equipment. Worm-holes allow you to speed your way across the map from/to fixed locations, although planetary objects locations will depend on their rotation around their star. Enemies, asteroids and debris seem to always re-spawn, making sure you never run out of things to do.

Cons: Every time you load the game up, you can continue with the same ship, equipment and money, but the game always regenerate a new sector, so there is no sense of accomplishment or progression. The graphics are retro, which just isn't my thing: I got to play games back when such graphics were the best that they got, but a nostalgia trip into retro" graphics and vintage-tech sound effects shouldn't be a thing in my opinion.

reviewText:
tl;dr This game is fun for a freebie. I'd probably pay a couple bucks if there were more guns and stuff.

One stand out feature of this game is the lack of inertia and near constant collisions. That can either be a good thing or a bad thing depending on how well you drive. If you're like me, you drive like â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and only fight near asteroids and use them to block incoming shots and missiles.

This is a rather fun little game that plays rather well on my i5 built in graphics ubuntu laptop (though there is some video tearing, which is to be expected). The graphics are adequate and interesting enough to keep you engaged. The sounds are good and fulfill their role. There's no soundtrack (so far as I can tell), and no story to speak of.

This sandbox space game is rather fun. There are orbiting stations you can dock at to sell your loot, planets to land on and clear of pirate outposts and bombing ships, and a lot of ships you can shoot in space. Asteroids are a frequent encounter too, yielding money when you blow them up. When you have enough money you can buy new ships or mercenaries to fight along side you. All in all, a fun little game.

One of the only things missing from this is a little more content. The amount of loot and such is rather limited and there's really not much reason to go past certain items once you get them. I'd personally prefer a few RPG elements and a story, but I kinda like the simplicity of this game. You just boot it up, load up your ship, and kill some pirates. And for that this game gets a recommend from me. It's just another bonus that this game happens to be free. I hope they make a sequel because this little game shows that you don't have to have HD graphics or be a AAA developer to produce a fun experience.

While it generally is quite a fun game to play, and is quite a good time waster, there are some things that put me off from really reccomending this game to people.
Here are my points,

1. After clearing out pirate activity on planets (At least, I assume the skull and crossbones mean pirate activity), there isn't much else of a goal to work towards. Sure, you can buy the biggest ship and get the best guns you can find, but, that's more of a means of getting somewhere, not a goal in itself.

2. Clearing out pirate activity. Now this may sound strange when you look back on point 1, but read on.
It's never really clear how you wipe out the pirates, but when you do it, you have no idea how or why the dangerzones have disappeared on the map. The only in-game goal in Destination Sol is basically clearing this out, but it seems so easy to do that it just seems that if I buy a bigger ship, they just disappear straight away.

3. Unclear main menu. There is hardly something in the way of options, you get just a few buttons for a set few resolutions, windowed or fullscreen, and sound volume from off to very high. While I am aware that this is a free game, there should've been put a little bit more thought into the options menu regardless.

4. Performance. While the game runs very smoothly on my low-end PC, there is one big glaring issue I have.
-It randomly freezes up my entire computer, thus having me hard-reset the thing-
I am unsure if this is the case for other people, but if it is, there need to be some patches made to fix this.


My suggestions would be to add clear objectives and goals to work towards, adding missions, making it clear how to fulfill those missions and objectives and when you have fulfilled them. Make the menu a little more clear, perhaps with some sliders, for example, for the sound volume, and patching the game so that it doesn't freeze up computers at random.



Minor nitpick: I have also run into some planet-related glitches. When tackling turrets on various planets, I often find myself warped into the terrain, unable to escape, thus having to exit the game and start a new one with my previous ship, or respawning (Which takes away some of your resources (Ammo, cash). Again, this is something that could be easily fixed.



All in all, I did find this an enjoyable game, but the lack of goals, some glitches and PC-Freezing make it less fun than it could have been.

I got exactly what I wanted: an arcade shooter with dosh-based equipment progression, a sizeable patch of open space to explore, with planets, asteroid belts, stars and cavernous planetoids with labirynthian tunnels. Cons:
- could use some quest or objectives system to add more variety
- monotone thruster sounds get tiring after a while
- only one save slot
- long-distance flight impeded by frequent collisions with random asteroids
Pros:
+ a selection of interesting and varied weaponry
+ ships with unique abilities, like slowing time, teleportation, enemy knockback etc.
+ cool seamless planet transitions
+ challenging and satisfying combat
+ nice graphics, especially on the planets
+ it's free, yet more of a game than many paid titles
+ based Slav devs

To sum it up: if you like arcade shooters, you should check this thing out. I did and I loved it.

reviewText:
Destination Sol is a very simple game, and I love it for that. it's a 2D space ship games that couldn't have been that hard to make, seeing as one of the very first video games was pretty much the same thing. Yet, despite it's addicting breed of shooting actiony gameplay, there are very few games that truly explore this genre.

This game is about half of what I want. I want to explore space and new planets and interact with a variety of people. I want to have harrowing space battles with pirates or rebels all while customizing my ship.

Really, Destination Sol is good, but it's not great, which isn't a surprise for a free game. There are plenty of unique weapons to experiment with, and the galaxy is large enough to occupy a good four or five hours, but after that, there isn't much to do. There are no people to talk to, and practically everything wants to kill you.

When you do die, which can be easy at times, you start back at the beginning of the game, and getting back to where you were is annoying because asteroids are so abundant you slam into them constantly (at least until you get to the light speed points, which are satisfying to use even if they take forever).

Getting into orbit around a planet is finicky as well. They don't actually have gravity unless you're extremely close to them, and they're so small that your engines just propel you right out of their atmosphere and back into space, which is annoying when you're trying to take down other orbiting ships.

Honestly, though, the game is free, and I suggest it to everyone even slightly interested. I'd be willing to pay money for this for the person to make it even better, even.

Let me tell you my story...

I was a young pilot, the galaxy was new, unimaginably massive, and my mind so small. With meager blaster in hand, shield and armor engaged, and thrusters firing, I was ready to take my first steps. The stars would tremble and shiver at my coming, the planets would bear the scars of my cannons. I was to be the greatest marauder the galaxy had ever seen. My mission was a single grand idea, a lone syllable to give me my purpose: Sol. Destination, Sol.

The first to feel my wrath was the nearby planet of Neso. Armed with naught but a humble Light Machinegun, I singlehandedly butchered their army, drifting like an ethereal sword through space and time, slaying them one by one until the only witness to the bloodshed was the planet, silent as a tomb. The nearby outpost thanked me for liberating them of their oppressors, and shared with me their stocks, for a modest price.

Next came the planet of... Neso. Far more dangerous, these formidable adversaries were armed from toe to teeth, each ship hefting a slug-spewing demon on one hand and its twin in the other. But they were little match for my sharp aim and flawless tactics. Their planet fell just as the last, and now I had a superior vessel, and now I could summon the demons.

Now I was ready to face the Miners. Famed for their ruthlessness, they stripped the comets on the edge of the system bare, leaving both their enemies and their mines silent husks. Their rockets and harpoons could savage an unwary ship in seconds, just another drop in the ocean of blood they had spilt. Their time had come. The comet sprawled wormlike, its brilliant passages meandering this way and that, the crystals sharp as an angel's pike. My hull groaned and scraped under the abuse, but I pushed onward. And in the center, there they were- But I had no time to bask in my discovery. Sirens blared as rockets and missiles homed in on me; I was nearly buried, not by rock, but by a ceaseless barrage of violence and hatred made into projectiles of fire. It was a hard-fought battle, and I feel no shame in saying that I had to call in a favor with some shadier friends. But once we were done, we knew the comet's gleam would remain eternally, for no miner would dare stray past the veritable ring of corpses we left behind.

Now there lay only one objective left for me. A mysterious planet orbitting Sol which had no name. It is said that the warriors that inhabit this place are without match in technology and prowess, their warlike muster unmatched by any empire or being.

Until now.

I descended upon their planet in my chariot of steel, striking rapid and graceful, now here then there, so that not a single shot could land upon me. Their armada decorated the snowy earth with fiery testaments to my wrath. From them I assimilated the most powerful arsenal in all of Sol, so that ships 5 times my size would shatter like panes of fetid glass.

And then I was alone. All the galaxy, having been laid low by my hand, stood yielding to the might of the Imperium. What else was I to do.

The thought set in. That was it. I had bested the gods of our worlds, the truly greatest warriors our universe had to offer.

I drifted away from the planet. What else was there to do? The pirates orbiting Sol would not dare touch me, fleeing from my grasp. My lances mercilessly violated the ones who dared stray into my path. Then I remembered, my purpose, my goal, my reason for existence. The thing that lay at the end of my bloody crusade. Sol.

As though fate knew my mind, as though some unseen hand was guiding me, I needed only lay still. I drifted slowly into the embrace of the Sun, Sol, the center of my ideology, the center of my being. It engulfed me in flame and wrath, and I laid submissive to its hunger. Sol, the only being that could best me, would be my judge. It held me in a trance, and my hands fell off the console like leaves in fall, leaving behind their purpose, seeking a higher level, some unatainable future.

Sol would consume me, just as I had consumed the galaxy.

reviewText:
This game is a good start but doesn't follow it's best notes to completion. That said, it is FREE, so all you lose is time.

The game art is really good. The tutorial is barebones but gets the job done. You start out with a small, weak ship that can only kill some satellites without too much danger. When you earn more money, you can get better ships. Even the second ship is good enough to fight some enemies with so you can do more. The combat with enemy ships was fun, but it was sometimes too hard to find them.

The game does a good job of communicating when you're near an enemy that will kick your butt too hard. One detail I loved is that if you fly too close to a sun, you start to take damage.

The problems with this game are mostly with the interface, specifically the camera. The only control problem is that you can only go forward and rotate. While it was somewhat cool to build speed and then fly backwards like the Space Shuttle reentering the atmosphere, it makes combat harder. The other problem is that because of the poor view, you have little time to react if an asteroid suddenly appears in your path. This is a big deal because collisions bypass your shields and damage your hull. The problem with this is that if you are stationary, you will automatically repair if you have a repair tool. If you have taken more than 2 or 3 points of damage, it will use up one tool, no matter if you are repairing 4 points of damage or 20. Unless you move or shoot, in which case it will stop, requiring you to use another tool if you want to repair again.

The camera troubles continue when approaching planets. It will swing around so the surface is below you, which is nice, but it gets annoying when you fly around that threshold and the camera keeps moving back and forth. Also, it's far too zoomed again, so you can't see the surface of the planet very well.

I did have some fun with the combat, but ultimately there isn't much to do.  The game is the base of a much better one.

I like the game, and it has defintely gave me some ideas and insight, but it needs the time put into it to create a fun experience.

Its a fun space exploration game without an aim... You go to a planet shoot all the enemies on it, move on to another one.. in another solar system. Fight enemies on your way, find space stations to sell your loot, buy new stuff, ships and hire helpers! As you progress throughout planets the enemies become more and more challenging, no matter how armored you are or what shields, weapons you have. Every planet also has its own trade center, so you can go around the planet, shooting every enemy and when you made it around the planet... You can proudly sell your loot or keep the goodies!

And now the stuff that i do not particulary enjoy about this game.
There are these flying trade centers that move around from planet to planet, to solar system to solar system. What i do not dislike about these flying trade centers is that its hard to get in the automatic door with your space ship.. because most of the time the trade center will be jerking around instead of staying still. Also they tend to fly in the Sun... which obviously ends up with you and the trade center burning to ashes.
The second thing is that the player and enemies / friendly's sometimes get stuck in a planet's ground... so the player or the NPC's are not visible nor you can shoot them.  This happpened to me once and i've seen atleast one enemy NPC get stuck underground..

Overall this is a great game, it's free to play and you should totally download it!

I've played this game before it came to steam.

This game is really amazing, even though the only thrust is using W and using your mouse to aim where to move and shoot.

You're able to eventually upgrade to better ships, buy better equipment such as Armor, Shields, and Weapons. You can destroy astroids which drop money, or you can either defeat enemy ships and loot the leftovers. Pirate ships occasionally drop equipment, although they're not the best.

I found this game really amazing and I see that it has great potential for to become one of my favorite F2P games.
I hope this game get's updates weekly/monthly atleast to improve the game and focus toward a more completed game that allows someone to invest many hours of playing this open-world rpg.

It's be nice to make the universe a lot bigger, maybe add in something to auto-generate the universe the further you go away from the starting zone. Eventually add a lot of more ships to upgrade to, a lot more of Armor, Shields, and Weapons. It'd be awesome to add mini-quests here and there also that give you rewards of rare equipment that you aren't able to buy.

Once again, I find that this has a LOT of potential to become a really great game that I can enjoy in my free time as I progress through the the universe. If this game eventually has multiplayer implemented, that'd make an interesting aspect to PvP and also raiding on enemy infested areas.

reviewText: Imagine the concept of the orrignal Asteroids game fleshed out into a more hardcore production. reviewText:
I know that I didn't give this game much time before writing this review. But I feel like I know what I should think about this.

Destination Sol is an interesting game. It's different. It's quite original. It has a nice feeling. And that's why I'm recommending it. But only because it's free.

The game doesn't feel finished. So if you're looking for an actual game to play this might bore you. It's like one of those games people make when they're still learning. And there's nothing wrong with that. It isn't buggy or anything. But it's just a bunch of mechanics and a sandbox environment to play with them. Games need goals. And this has none. If it had one I might've spent more time playing. And who knows - maybe I'll seeing that this game is still being developed.


tl;dr Interesting mechanics, but no goal. Might get boring. But things might change in future.

reviewText:
I guess I shouldn't be complaining since this was a zero-cost game, but I still feel the urge to convey what I feel. Perhaps I can't say for sure whether the game is good or not, since I've only played it for 1.7 hours. But I cannot recommend this to other players at the moment.

I went into this game with high expectations; sure, it was a freebie, but it got very positive reviews. But after 1.7 hours, here is how I feel.

There isn't an overarching plot or story to the game. Sure, you pilot your ship around between two systems, fire your blaster or machine gun at anything orange on screen, earn some money, trade your ship in for a bigger one, etc. etc. But, in the end, since there isn't a story for the game, I can't feel that there is an end goal to reach towards, and I feel no sense of accomplishment for anything that I do in this game.

Pros:
- Simple controls
- Free roaming/Open universe
- Space!

Cons:
- No music
- So little content
- No plot or purpose

If this game were an early beta release, or if the developers are merely showcasing what they can do, I would understand that. Once again, this is a freebie, so knock yourself out if you want to try it out. But, considering my feelings, I can't recommend it. Perhaps, in the future, updates will be provided that will give it what I am looking for; then, I might try it out again. But as it stand, I'd give it a D+.

Hello!

A great recommendation for all comers, not only because of the no-price offer, but because it is an amazingly well-built game.

reviewText:
Long Review:

It's games like these that make me wish Steam offered more options for reviews than just recommended and not recommended. This game certainly has a lot of potential and I am excited to see what it becomes in the future, however, in it's current state it seems fairly empty to me. Destination Sol has all the mechanics it needs to become a great game, but it seems almost devoid of content at this point, I mean, it's tagged as an RPG but doesn't even have any quests (I think, I havn't played a massive amount). When this game gets some content to make it feel less empty, I will wholeheartedly recommend it, until then, I give it a 5/10, however if you're just looking for something to waste a couple minutes on, get it now, it's free, there's no reason not to, but if you are looking for an immersive gaming experience to play for hours on end, I see no reason to download this game.

Quick Review:

Pros -
1. Free.
2. Fun if you just want to blow stuff up and crash into things, and admit it, we all want to do that sometimes.

Cons-
1. Is quite empty in it's current state.

Tips For Developer:
1. ADD CONTENT! At this point Destination Sol is all mechanics and nearly nothing else.
2. Change the name, unless I'm completely missing the point of the game and I'm supposed to be going to the Sol system instead of wandering around fighting pirates, the name doesn't really fit with the rest of the game.
3. Make the ship respawn automatically when you die, it makes the game seem more polished, just a tip though, not really a major thing to fix.
4. Change the title screen, when I first got to the title screen I thought I had accidentally downloaded a horror game, it just looks like it would set the mood for a horror game better, try a sleek, futuristic look for the title screen if you change it.

The basic mechanics of this game are sound, and very fun. It's a great F2P.

I don't think it would make a great paid game because it feels incomplete. With new enemies, areas, environments, planets, weapons, equipment and ships it could be really interesting. In it's current stage there just isn't enough content to keep you interested for very long.

reviewText:
Cons:
game structure is very standard, you start with a boring small ship, and then go places and can buy better ships and upgrade stuff. commonly in this kind of game you come across several small upgrades or access options that match your strategies/play style, and help lure you with hints of bigger weapons  to continue. Surprisingly, there is very little accessible for a good while into the game (as an hour into the game i found 4 competent weapons, two of which vagualy matched my preferences), as well as minimal customization options (you can get a ship that has a single slot for one weapon type as opposed to a ship that has a single slot for another weapon type).
the ship is controlled by exactly one thruster, meaning you accelerate in the direction you are facing, which can work in some games and some layouts. however, the turn rate is frustratingly slow and overtorqued, in the way that if you land on a planet (which considering it was highlighted feature is annoying to find it has absolutely no use) and you move your mouse slightly (the turn control and ALSO used to access your menu), you rock and roll around in a ridiculous manner, possibly causing damage to yourself and potentially moving into the line of fire of one of the generated enemies (did i mention that the only way to pause in-game time is to enter the main menu?).
pros (kinda):
i will say the transition between outer-space and planetary space is seamless, although it was very disorienting the first several times as there is NO indication that your frame of reference shifts as you approach a planet and that the compass that sometimes appears is an idiation of 'universal north'.
I have not looked into the open-source aspect of the game, but other than the point on the shop page, there is no indication of it in-game, or anywhere else i saw (i didnt look very hard either).
the game is truly as it claims to be when it says it is free, so i have no complaints about that.
it is also smooth/solid fps, which is cool and enables you too see nice details on the planet surfaces like trees and snow, but it also makes it very easy to see all the things that are not-so-nice.

TLDR:
basic rpg-ish with slow progression, there are no instructions at all, no key binding options, the controls overlap, messed-up motion mechanics, minimal items, interesting physics/inertia, entirely actually free, smooth, interesting graphics.
